Translation of 郭店楚簡-忠信之道(en) into English.

p.seg: 1.1A Not to [be] pretentious and not to [be] destructive, that is the culmination of trueheartedness;
1.1B Not to cheat and to avoid cunning, [A] that is the culmination of trustworthiness;
1.2A When trueheartedness is accumulated [by the junzi] [B] then [he] can be felt close to [by the people];
1.2B When trustworthiness is accumulated [by the junzi], then [he] can be trusted [by the people];
1.C That trueheartedness and trustworthiness have been accumulated [by the junz ] and the people refuse to get close to and trust [him]—
there has never been such a case.
2.1A The highest trueheartedness is like the soil;
it develops the things but does not attack them; [C]
2.1B The highest trustworthiness is like the seasons,
[they] necessarily arrive but [the circle] does not break off.
2.2A Men of trueheartedness have no pretension;
2.2B Men of trustworthiness are not perfidious
2.C The sovereign (junz ) goes along with this,
and therefore [he] does not cheat [upon] life, nor is [he] perfidious [upon] death.
3.A To hold old ways in high esteem and never counteract [D] [them],
that is trueheartedness in its culmination;
3.B To hold antiquity in high reverence and take it as principle,
that is trustworthiness in its culmination.
3.C The highest trueheartedness has no pretension;
The highest trustworthiness is not perfidious;
That is what this is about.
4.1A The highest trueheartedness is not pleasant for [the people];
4.1B The highest trustworthiness is not restricted in time; [E]
4.2A Not pleasant for [the people] [and yet] providing enough to nourish, such is the Earth;
4.2B Not to be restricted in time [and yet] able to restrain [others], such is Heaven. [F]
4.C To follow Heaven and Earth is what trueheartedness and trustworthiness are about.
As for everently following heaven and earth, that is what zhōng and xìn refer to.
5.1 If [only] kind with words, but factually not acting in accordance with them,
the sovereign (junz ) rather refrains from speaking;
5.2 If letting the mind loose,
and yet being intimate in [one’s] appearance, the sovereign (junz ) rather refrains from displaying [this];
5.3 If acting according to the old, but pleasing the people by serving [them thespecial taste of] zheng, [G]
the sovereign (junz ) rather refrains from relying on this.
5.C As to these three [fallacies], the truehearted man would refrain from doing [so],
and the trustworthy man would refrain from acting [accordingly].
6.1A When trueheartedness becomes the way [in the state],
[then] all kinds of skilled labour will not decay, and the nourishing of the people will [thus] all be sufficient;
6.1B [And] when trustworthiness becomes the way [in the state],
all groups of things will be completed, and all goods will [thus] be established.
6.2A [As a consequence] when the conduct of the sovereign (junz ) indeed [turns out to be] truehearted,
for this reason, [even] the Mán barbarians come close to and follow [him];
6.2B [And] when words [of the sovereign] indeed [turn out to be] trustworthy,
for this reason, [they] are sincere and can be endured.[H]
6.C Trueheartedness is the realization of benevolence (rén);
[And] trustworthiness is the limitation for righteousness (yì).
It was for this reason that [the sovereign] in the days of old [even] applied this principle towards the Mán and Mò barbarians.
